Row.Text: Great Aviator
Great Aviator
Great Aviator unit description
Air Shows
+10 [Icon_GreatAviator] Great Aviator points per turn
Space Camp
+7 [Icon_GreatAviator] Great Aviator points per turn, and +12 [Icon_GreatAviator] Great Aviator points per turn for every airport.
Sir George Cayley
Triggers the [Icon_TechBoosted] Eureka moments for Flight, Advanced Flight, Lasers, and Stealth Technology.
Orville Wright
Grants a biplane unit and +1 [ICON_RESOURCE_OIL] Oil per turn.
Wilbur Wright
Instantly builds a hangar in this district. Hangars grant +2 [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production.
Thaddeus S. C. Lowe
Grants an observation balloon unit. Observation balloons and drones gain +1 vision.
Thaddeus S. C. Lowe's Legacy
+1 vision (Thaddeus S. C. Lowe)
René Lorin
Air bomber units gain +2 [ICON_Range] attack range.
Rene's Range
+2 [ICON_Range] attack range (René Lorin)
Chuck's Chuckle
+1 [ICON_Range] attack range (Chuck Yeager)
Manfred Albrecht Freiherr von Richthofen
Air fighter class units gain +10 [ICON_STRENGTH] combat strength against other aircraft.
Bloodlust of the Baron
+10 [ICON_STRENGTH] combat strength (Red Baron)
Percival E. Fansler
Hangars and Airports cost nothing to maintain and instead provide +6 [ICON_GOLD] Gold and +10 [ICON_GOLD] Gold respectfully.
Alberto Santos-Dumont
Gain +5% [ICON_SCIENCE] Science and +5% [ICON_CULTURE] Culture while not at war.
Amelia Earhart
Grants 1500 [ICON_CULTURE] Culture on standard speed. Must be activated on or adjacent to a reef.
Carl Richard Nyberg
Instantly builds a hangar and airport in this district. Airports grant +4 [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production.
Radoje Ljutovac
Land based anti aircraft support units gain +10 anti aircraft strength.
Will of Radoje Ljutovac
+10 anti aircraft strength (Radoje Ljutovac)
Floyd Fogleman
+20% [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production towards aircraft.
Clément Ader
Aircraft carriers gain +10 [ICON_STRENGTH] combat strength. +30% [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production towards aircraft carriers.
Clement-time
+10 [ICON_STRENGTH] combat strength (Clément Ader)
Hermann Ganswindt
Grants a helicopter unit with one promotion level and +1 [ICON_RESOURCE_ALUMINUM] Aluminum per turn.
Hermann Ganswindt
Naval units with an anti aircraft stat gain +10 anti aircraft strength.
Ghost of Gustav Rasmus
+10 anti aircraft strength (Gustav Rasmus)
Chuck Yeager
Air fighter units gain +1 [ICON_Range] attack range.
Douglas Douglas-Hamilton
Grants 150 [ICON_CULTURE] Culture for each adjacent grass, plains, or desert mountain, and 300 [ICON_CULTURE] Culture or each adjacent tundra or snow mountain.
Robert Hutchings Goddard
Grants +50% [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production towards space race projects.
Industrial Era
Just a regular ol' Industrial Era nothing to see here
Modern Era
Just a regular ol' Modern Era nothing to see here
Atomic Era
Just a regular ol' Atomic Era nothing to see here
Information Era
Just a regular ol' Information Era nothing to see here

An American Air force pilot with an extensive service history, Chuck Yeager earned his spot in history as the first human being confirmed to have broken the sound barrier, during a test flight on October 14th of 1947.
Quite frankly everything else he’s done isn’t nearly as sick and rad as that, no matter how important they may have been historically.

A pioneer for both aviation and suffrage, Amelia Earhart is perhaps most well known for time she did not fly successfully. The first woman to fly solo across the Atlantic ocean, and an accomplished writer, Earhart is also credited with helping form the ninety nines, an organization of female pilots.

Earhart was a major proponent of commercial flight, and her writing on the subject was instrumental in normalizing the practice. As a child, I assumed that her last name was spelled “Airheart” and quite frankly I think the world would be a better place if it was.

The mustached variant of the famous wright brothers, Orville Wright is largely considered one of the most prominent figures in the invention of human flight, particularly among the residents of kitty hawk.

Though historians are unable to agree on whether or not the idea for fixed wing lift was inspired by his facial hair, he has nonetheless secured his place in history as one of the first fathers of flight.

The smooth faced variant of the famous wright brothers, Wilbur Wright is largely considered one of the most prominent figures in the invention of human flight, particularly among the residents of kitty hawk.

Though historians are unable to agree on whether or not his lack of hair contributed to a greater understanding of air pressure like the newly awakened airbenders in the era of avatar Korra, he has nonetheless secured his place in history as one of the first fathers of flight.

Often accredited as the earliest true scientific aerial investigator, Sir George Cayley would perish long before the dream of flight was accomplished by humans. His contributions were years ahead of his time, even going so far as to propose a realistic system for vertical flight.
Having identified the four forces that act on heavier than air vehicles, Cayley is often considered one of the most important individuals in the history of aeronautics.

An American civil war aeronaut, Thaddeus S. C. Lowe contributed to a Union victory through the contribution of aerial reconnaissance. Aside from contributing advanced theories in meteorological sciences, he was revered in his time for expert balloon building.
Lowe also earned millions through his patent of an ice making machine, just an all around cool and fun guy.
Largely considered the greatest combat pilot of his time, Manfred Albrecht Freiherr von Richthofen earned the notorious title of “red baron” for his time in the German air force during world war I.
Vicious rival of Snoopy the dog, Manfred earned his title through bloody combat in what was largely considered the golden age of aerial dogfighting.

A scientist well ahead of his time, Lorin patented FR390256 in 1908, the first subsonic ramjet design. His invention could not be tested for many years, as there was no way for an aircraft to reach the speed necessary for ramjet operation at the time.
Rene Lorin would never live to see his innovation in action, as the first successful operation of a ramjet was not until 1945, well after his death in 1933.
Percival E. Fansler’s claim to fame was the operation of the first commercial airline between St. Petersburg and Tampa in 1914. He was joined by the first federally licensed pilot, Anthony H Jannus.
The historic first flight of the airline featured only a single passenger, but was witnessed by over 3000 civilians on January 1st 1914.

One of the few aviators to rival the wright brothers in the early days of heavier-than-air flight, Alberto Santos-Dumont was a Brazilian born heir to a fortune, that spent most of his life advancing flight in France.

Though Dumont achieved much of his heavier-than-air success later than the wright brothers, the secrecy in which the brothers conducted their flight, the patent process, and the slow communications of the time meant that for a brief period, France believed they had achieved it first. Dumont’s achievments also include winning a cash prize for flying around the eiffel tower that he promptly donated to charity, and sporting a moustache that surpassed even Orville Wright.
Carl Richard Nyberg was a Swedish inventor and industrialist best known for his invention of the blow torch (which in itself greatly helped the field of aviation).
His specific aviation contributions include the creation of the steam engine aircraft, earning him the moniker “Carl Nyberg the Aviator Science Guyberg”.

Radoje Ljutovac was a Serbian soldier from the village of Poljna, Serbia. Private Radoje Ljutovac fought in the First World War in the Serbian Army, and is officially credited with the first shooting down of a military aircraft with Ground-to-Air artillery fire.

However, the artillery in question was not the dedicated anti-aircraft guns we know today, but rather a common field cannon mounted on the back of a cart, pulled by a horse. The downing of the aircraft was nothing short of a truly remarkable, and quite frankly hilarious, show of skill.
Floyd Fogleman was an aviation designer credited with helping design stepped airfoils along with Richard Kline in the 1960s.
Though it sees use in full sized aircraft in the modern day, its original conception was for use in high quality competitive paper planes.
Clément Ader was a French inventor and engineer remembered primarily for his pioneering work in aviation and supporting the sport of cycling in France.

Many of his air prototypes were developed before the turn of the 20th century and were largely unsuccessful, but was forward thinking enough to publish a practical design for aircraft carriers long before heavier than air flight was widely adopted.

Hermann Ganswindt was a German inventor and spaceflight scientist, whose inventions such as the dirigible, the helicopter, and the internal combustion engine are thought to have been ahead of his time, having been born in only 1856.

Perhaps his silliest intellectual ideation was the concept of a two stage spacecraft propelled by a series of dynamite detonations. Though not practical, many critics of the design could not refute that it would have been sick and rad.

Air Commodore Douglas Douglas-Hamilton, 14th Duke of Hamilton and 11th Duke of Brandon, KT, GCVO, AFC, PC, DL, FRCSE, FRGS was a Scottish nobleman and aviator who was the first man to fly over Mount Everest.

Records of his historic flight lack video records, but it is widely believed he held an enormous smirk as he flew over, shouting “nice job climbing you dummies! You’ll never get as high as me!” out the window, causing massive humiliation to a climber about to plant a flag at the peak.
The first to propose the concept of a surface to air missile (SAM), Gustav Rasmus originally proposed homing in on the sound of an aircraft’s engine.
Though laser guided models would eventually dominate the field of surface to air missiles, this was the only inventor I could reasonably justify having this ability as a great aviator.

By the time of his death in August 1945 AD, Robert Goddard held some 214 patents, had dreamed large (envisioning a rocket reaching the Moon), had touched space (well, 2.6 kilometers in altitude), and is said to be the “father of rocketry.” His 1919 monograph “A Method for Reaching Extreme Altitudes” is considered the classic text of early rocket science. Not a bad legacy.

Goddard enrolled in the Worcester (Massachusetts) Polytechnic Institute in his hometown in 1907, where he became infamous for trying to set off a black-powder rocket from the laboratory basement. He received his Bachelor of Science degree in 1908, and subsequently took his masters and doctorate degrees in physics from Clark University. In 1912 he accepted a position at the Palmer Labs at Princeton, but soon returned to teach part-time at Clark University where he was free to pursue his “peculiar” interest in rocketry. In 1915, Goddard launched his first successful rocket, this time outside the building at Clark.

But by 1916 his research had become too costly for his modest salary to bear; having gained some interest through his writings, he convinced the Smithsonian Institute the next year to give him a five-year grant totaling 5000 dollars. Clark University also agreed to give him some funding. With this largess, which continued from various contributors, Goddard perfected his earlier ideas, among these two basic advances that made space travel possible: multi-stage rockets, and liquid rocket fuel.
